meanings.definition: A flower bud that is not fully developed or has not yet bloomed.
meanings.sent1: The underbud on the rose bush was small and tightly closed.
meanings.sent2: The gardener carefully watched the underbud, waiting for it to blossom.
meanings.sent3: The underbud whispered to the other flowers, 'I'm the late bloomer of the group!'
meanings.sent4: Her potential was an underbud waiting to burst into full bloom.
meanings.sent5: The underbud held the promise of a beautiful flower to come.

meanings.definition: To develop or grow beneath another bud.
meanings.sent1: The new shoot began to underbud beneath the larger branch.
meanings.sent2: The plant seemed to underbud in unexpected places, surprising the gardener.
meanings.sent3: The flowers giggled as they watched the buds underbud in a race to grow.
meanings.sent4: His talent started to underbud, slowly emerging as a hidden strength.
meanings.sent5: The idea began to underbud in her mind, growing quietly but steadily.

meanings.definition: To be inferior or less advanced than something else.
meanings.sent1: Her skills seemed to underbud compared to her classmates.
meanings.sent2: The smaller plant would always underbud in the shadow of the taller ones.
meanings.sent3: The underbud of the team joked, 'I'm the underdog in this competition!'
meanings.sent4: His confidence started to underbud, overshadowed by self-doubt.
meanings.sent5: The town's technology would always underbud behind the bustling city.
